posts.cooked: Whenever I power cycle the robot, our brand new Limelight 4 will not turn on. occasionally, it will turn on, but we can’t figure out what happened to make it work again.

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: just to make it quicker for the people who actually know stuff, what’s your wiring look like?
Until you send us info about how it’s powered, I’d remove power from it before you accidentally damage it.

WIN_20250211_18_31_31_Pro 1280×720 187 KB

WIN_20250211_18_31_31_Pro 1280×720 187 KB

WIN_20250211_18_31_31_Pro 1280×720 187 KB

20 amp fuse? circuit breaker? idk I am not the wiring team.
sent it into the main thread on accident

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked:
Couple things to look at:

Check the top of the fuse, it should say what its rated for (i think the yellow ones are 5A, but I could be wrong), they should be 5A ideally

Ensure both ends of the wire are making proper contact with the connectors (like make sure the wires going into the PDH are long enough), on the side going into the limelight it looks like your using ferrules which should be, but I can’t tell what is going into the PDH .

Ideally make sure its 20-18 gauge wire as stated by the FRC Wiring | Limelight Documentation

Make sure the crimps on the ferrules are sufficient

That should give you some sort of baseline as to what’s wrong, but I’m not an expert, always consult the wiring guide on the Limelight website.

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: Don’t connect the USB C connector.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked:
A couple of things to try:

Make sure the wire is stripped enough to contact the PDH ports and ferrules in case the connection isn’t good. Also, switch the 20A fuses to a 5A or a 10A, it should be 5A ideally so 20A is too high.

Try switching to a different PDH port, we’ve run into power issues where the issue was a bad port.

If nothing you try works, you could try using POE to power instead. If you’re using one of the new radios, just connect the limelight to one of the radio’s aux ports via ethernet. Make sure to flip the corresponding dip switch on so the port can supply power. Doing this makes it so the radio provides 12V to downstream devices which is the limelight in this case. Check the VH-109 wiring docs just to make sure you’re doing this right

Also, make sure to check any wiring docs on the Limelight 4, I’ve never wired a 4 so I don’t know if anything has changed since the 3G, I wouldn’t want my information to be incorrect. Good luck with the issue.

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: Never mind about the POE then, just continue checking your connection to the Limelight, and make sure that there isn’t any damage to the wires or ferrules. If you really wanted to, you could take a multimeter to check voltage or continuity. If either test comes back bad, try making a new wire for bad continuity or switching the PDH port for voltage issues.
